message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Xatkit: A Multimodal Low-Code Chatbot Development Framework
Paper Abstract: Chatbot (and voicebot) applications are increasingly adopted in various domains such as e-commerce or customer services as a direct communication channel between companies and end-users. Multiple frameworks have been developed to ease their definition and deployment. While these frameworks are efficient to design simple chatbot applications, they still require advanced technical knowledge to define complex interactions and are difficult to evolve along with the company needs (e.g. it is typically impossible to change the NL engine provider). In addition, the deployment of a chatbot application usually requires a deep understanding of the targeted platforms, especially back-end connections, increasing the development and maintenance costs. In this paper, we introduce the Xatkit framework. Xatkit tackles these issues by providing a set of Domain Specific Languages to define chatbots (and voicebots and bots in general) in a platform-independent way. Xatkit also comes with a runtime engine that automatically deploys the chatbot application and manages the defined conversation logic over the platforms of choice. Xatkit's modular architecture facilitates the separate evolution of any of its components. Xatkit is open source and fully available online.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about voicebots:

A voicebot is closely related to the broader category of chatbots. A chatbot is a software application or web interface designed to have textual or spoken conversations. When a chatbot specifically uses voice, it becomes a voicebot.

The technology behind voicebots relies on voice user interfaces. A voice-user interface (VUI) enables spoken human interaction with computers, using speech recognition to understand spoken commands and answer questions, and typically text to speech to play a reply.

Voicebots fall under the broader field of voice computing, which is the discipline that develops hardware or software to process voice inputs.(no content)Voice user interfaces are the primary way of interacting with virtual assistants on smartphones and smart speakers.

The search results show that voicebots and voice-based AI systems have become increasingly prevalent in modern applications, with examples including smart speakers and virtual assistants that use advanced speech recognition and text-to-speech technologies.

I've performed a web search for "natural language processing." Here's what I found:

## Overview

Natural language processing (NLP) is the processing of natural language information by a computer and is a subfield of computer science closely associated with artificial intelligence.(no content)NLP is also related to information retrieval, knowledge representation, computational linguistics, and linguistics more broadly.

## Key Tasks

Major processing tasks in an NLP system include: speech recognition, text classification, natural language understanding, and natural language generation.

## Historical Development

Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s.(no content)Up until the 1980s, most natural language processing systems were based on complex sets of hand-written rules, but starting in the late 1980s, there was a revolution in natural language processing with the introduction of machine learning algorithms for language processing.(no content)The "Attention is All You Need" paper introduced the Transformer architecture in 2017, and the concept of large language model (LLM) emerged in late 2010s.(no content)In recent years, advancements in deep learning and large language models have significantly enhanced the capabilities of natural language processing, leading to widespread applications in areas such as healthcare, customer service, and content generation.

Web search results for query: "modular architecture software"

Links: [{"title":"Modular programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modular_programming"},{"title":"Modular Product Architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modular_Product_Architecture"},{"title":"Modular design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modular_design"},{"title":"Integrated modular avionics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrated_modular_avionics"},{"title":"VisualVM - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VisualVM"},{"title":"Modular Approach to Software Construction Operation and Test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modular_Approach_to_Software_Construction_Operation_and_Test"}]

Here are the search results for modular architecture software:

## Key Information About Modular Software Architecture

**Definition:**
Modular programming is a programming paradigm that emphasizes organizing the functions of a codebase into independent modules – each providing an aspect of a computer program in entirety without providing other aspects.

**Benefits:**
Modular designed systems, if built correctly, are far more reusable than traditional monolithic design, since modules may be reused (without change) in other projects. Additionally, this approach allows developers to build programs more efficiently by reusing existing modules as needed, reducing redundancy and promoting cleaner, more maintainable code.

**Team Structure:**
A modularized software project will be more easily assembled by large teams, since no team members are creating the whole system, or even need to know about the system as a whole.

**Module Design:**
A modular design can be characterized by functional partitioning into discrete scalable and reusable modules, rigorous use of well-defined modular interfaces, and making use of industry standards for interfaces.

**Modern Usage:**
Modular programming is now widespread, and found in virtually all major languages developed since the 1990s.

The search results also reference specific methodologies like MASCOT (Modular Approach to Software Construction Operation and Test), which was developed in the 1970s, and modern implementations in various programming languages.

I've completed the web search for "e-commerce". Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

E-commerce (electronic commerce) refers to commercial activities including the electronic buying or selling products and services which are conducted on online platforms or over the Internet.(no content)E-commerce typically uses the web for at least a part of a transaction's life cycle although it may also use other technologies such as e-mail.

## Types of E-commerce

There are three areas of e-commerce: online retailing, electronic markets, and online auctions. Additionally, the 6 types of business models that can be used in e-commerce include: Business-to-Consumer (B2C), Consumer-to-Business (C2B), Business-to-Business (B2B), Consumer-to-Consumer (C2C), Business-to-Administration (B2A), and Consumer-to-Administration.

## Common Applications

Typical e-commerce transactions include the purchase of products (such as books from Amazon) or services (such as music downloads in the form of digital distribution such as the iTunes Store).(no content)E-commerce businesses may also employ some or all of the following: Online shopping for retail sales direct to consumers via web sites and mobile apps, conversational commerce via live chat, chatbots, and voice assistants.

## Technologies Supporting E-commerce

E-commerce draws on technologies such as mobile commerce, electronic funds transfer, supply chain management, Internet marketing, online transaction processing, electronic data interchange (EDI), inventory management systems, and automated data collection systems.

## Definition and Overview

E-commerce (electronic commerce) refers to commercial activities including the electronic buying or selling products and services which are conducted on online platforms or over the Internet.(no content)E-commerce typically uses the web for at least a part of a transaction's life cycle although it may also use other technologies such as e-mail.

## Types of E-commerce

There are three areas of e-commerce: online retailing, electronic markets, and online auctions. Additionally, the 6 types of business models that can be used in e-commerce include: Business-to-Consumer (B2C), Consumer-to-Business (C2B), Business-to-Business (B2B), Consumer-to-Consumer (C2C), Business-to-Administration (B2A), and Consumer-to-Administration.

## Common Applications

Typical e-commerce transactions include the purchase of products (such as books from Amazon) or services (such as music downloads in the form of digital distribution such as the iTunes Store).(no content)E-commerce businesses may also employ some or all of the following: Online shopping for retail sales direct to consumers via web sites and mobile apps, conversational commerce via live chat, chatbots, and voice assistants.

## Technologies Supporting E-commerce

E-commerce draws on technologies such as mobile commerce, electronic funds transfer, supply chain management, Internet marketing, online transaction processing, electronic data interchange (EDI), inventory management systems, and automated data collection systems.

I've completed a web search for "customer service" and found comprehensive information. Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Customer service is the assistance and advice provided by a company to those who buy or use its products or services, either in person or remotely.(no content)Customer service is often practiced in a way that reflects the strategies and values of a firm, and levels vary according to the industry.

## Service Delivery Methods

Customer service representatives typically provide services by phone, but some also interact with customers face to face, by email or text, via live chat, and through social media.(no content)An advantage of automation is that it can provide service 24 hours a day which can complement face-to-face customer service.

## Technology and AI Integration

Many organisations have already adopted AI chatbots to improve their customer service experience.(no content)The customer benefit of AI is the feel for chatting with a live agent through improved speech technologies while giving customers the self-service benefit. AI can learn through interaction to give a personalized service.

## Customer Support vs. Customer Service

Customer support is a range of services to assist customers in making cost effective and correct use of a product. It includes assistance in planning, installation, training, troubleshooting, maintenance, upgrading, and disposal of a product.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "domain specific language"

Links: [{"title":"Domain-specific language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain-specific_language"},{"title":"Domain-specific modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain-specific_modeling"},{"title":"Talk:Domain-specific language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Domain-specific_language"},{"title":"Category:Domain-specific programming languages - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Domain-specific_programming_languages"},{"title":"Domain-specific multimodeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain-specific_multimodeling"},{"title":"Semantic domain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_domain"},{"title":"Planning Domain Definition Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planning_Domain_Definition_Language"},{"title":"SAS language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAS_language"},{"title":"General-purpose language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General-purpose_language"},{"title":"Automatic taxonomy construction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_taxonomy_construction"}]

Here are the search results for **domain specific language**:

## Overview

A domain-specific language (DSL) is a computer language specialized to a particular application domain.(no content)This is in contrast to a general-purpose language (GPL), which is broadly applicable across domains.

## Types and Examples

There are a wide variety of DSLs, ranging from widely used languages for common domains, such as HTML for web pages, down to languages used by only one or a few pieces of software, such as MUSH soft code.(no content)DSLs can be further subdivided by the kind of language, and include domain-specific markup languages, domain-specific modeling languages (more generally, specification languages), and domain-specific programming languages.

## Design and Characteristics

A domain-specific language is created specifically to solve problems in a particular domain and is not intended to be able to solve problems outside of it (although that may be technically possible).(no content)Creating a domain-specific language (with software to support it), rather than reusing an existing language, can be worthwhile if the language allows a particular type of problem or solution to be expressed more clearly than an existing language would allow and the type of problem in question reappears sufficiently often.

## Domain-Specific Modeling

Domain-specific modeling often includes the idea of code generation: automating the creation of executable source code directly from the domain-specific language models. Being free from the manual creation and maintenance of source code means domain-specific language can significantly improve developer productivity. The reliability of automatic generation compared to manual coding will also reduce the number of defects in the resulting programs thus improving quality.

Links: [{"title":"Chatbot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chatbot"},{"title":"Category:Chatbots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Chatbots"},{"title":"Gemini (chatbot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gemini_(chatbot)"},{"title":"Grok (chatbot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grok_(chatbot)"},{"title":"List of chatbots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_chatbots"},{"title":"DeepSeek (chatbot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DeepSeek_(chatbot)"},{"title":"Tay (chatbot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tay_(chatbot)"},{"title":"Kimi (chatbot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kimi_(chatbot)"},{"title":"Alice AI (AI model family) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alice_AI_(AI_model_family)"}]

Here are the search results for "chatbot":

## Definition and Overview

A chatbot (originally chatterbot) is a software application or web interface designed to have textual or spoken conversations.(no content)Modern chatbots are typically online and use generative artificial intelligence systems that are capable of maintaining a conversation with a user in natural language and simulating the way a human would behave as a conversational partner.

## Current Popularity

Chatbots have increased in popularity as part of the AI boom of the 2020s, and the popularity of ChatGPT, followed by competitors such as Gemini, Claude and later Grok.

## Technology

AI chatbots typically use a foundational large language model, such as GPT-4 or the Gemini language model, which is fine-tuned for specific uses.

## Applications

A major area where chatbots have long been used is customer service and support, with various sorts of virtual assistants.(no content)Many banks, insurers, media companies, e-commerce companies, airlines, hotel chains, retailers, health care providers, government entities, and restaurant chains have used chatbots to answer simple questions, increase customer engagement, for promotion, and to offer additional ways to order from them.

## Popular Chatbots

Recent notable chatbots include:
- Gemini (formerly known as Bard) is a generative artificial intelligence chatbot and virtual assistant developed by Google, based on the large language model (LLM) of the same name, launched on March 21, 2023 in response to the rise of OpenAI's ChatGPT.
- Grok is a generative artificial intelligence (generative AI) chatbot developed by xAI, launched in November 2023 by Elon Musk.
- DeepSeek is a generative artificial intelligence chatbot by the Chinese company DeepSeek, released on 20 January 2025, with DeepSeek-R1 surpassing ChatGPT as the most downloaded freeware app on the iOS App Store in the United States by 27 January.

Recent notable chatbots include:
- Gemini (formerly known as Bard) is a generative artificial intelligence chatbot and virtual assistant developed by Google, based on the large language model (LLM) of the same name, launched on March 21, 2023 in response to the rise of OpenAI's ChatGPT.
- Grok is a generative artificial intelligence (generative AI) chatbot developed by xAI, launched in November 2023 by Elon Musk.
- DeepSeek is a generative artificial intelligence chatbot by the Chinese company DeepSeek, released on 20 January 2025, with DeepSeek-R1 surpassing ChatGPT as the most downloaded freeware app on the iOS App Store in the United States by 27 January.

## Technology

AI chatbots typically use a foundational large language model, such as GPT-4 or the Gemini language model, which is fine-tuned for specific uses.
